THE FUTURE OF ATHLETICS

Last season Hopkins put out a lacrosse team that won the national championship. The student body was, naturally, pleased
-and delighted; they are looking forward to another successful
year, for they like to watch their team win games. Saturday night
the Varsity Club, by dint of careful planning, Staged a highly successful smoker for some of the more prominent prep school men
in the state. Incidently- they managed to make the trophy room
look presentable for the first time in the memory of the oldest
living undergraduate. "Fine!" says the student body, "An excellent idea." For the past few seasons swimming has been the
only winter sport at the university. "What about basketball ?"
says the student body, and "We want a soccer team."
Thus it is plain that this mass of undergraduates, termed the
student body, has excellent intentions. In other words, it has
the right idea. It remains to be seen whether the men who make
it up have as much ability to act as they have to applaud or criticise. They may say that, taken as a whole, they are not athletes,
that there is nothing for them to do. But there is one thing that
they can do, a thing that must be done
The sports at Hopkins need money. A certain amount must
be gotten, in order that the existing teams be properly equipped.
With a greater sum new sports can be taken up.
A successful spring season ticket campaign means an advance
in Hopkins athletics; poor returns mean retrogression. The issue is put squarely into the hands of the student body, which has
always been quick enough to advise or encourage. Two or three
sales per man means success.

GONE ARE THE DAYS
During these spring days, when the activities, one after another are holding elections, and passing the leadership down to the
men of the junior class, we notice the almost complete absence
of a spirit which has too often been dominant on the campus.
No longer do such rumors as "So and so has twenty proxies,"
or "such and such fraternities • have combined" fly about the
campus. Politics on the campus seems very nearly a thing of
the past. The credit belongs to the senior class. Taken as a
group, the seniors are not as strong in numbers or in outstanding
men as some of the classes of former years; they have perhaps.
not made as many contributions to undergraduate life; but they
have accomplished a thing which before seemed practically impossible.
•
One wishing to be cynical might say that they lacked the
brains to play politics, but this is obviously an unfair statement.
The one thing Which marks the men who have directed the activities this year is a spirit of fair play and of mutual trust.
This all may sound like sentimental rot. Sentimental it may
be, but it is not rot by any means. The NEWS-LETUR has deplored conditions of former years too often to overlook the present change for the better. The situation has only one drawback;
future editors will be deprived of a fertile subject for burning
reform articles.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 15, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
In an effort to enlighten the college man regarding the opportunities in various businesses and professions, Bowdoin College has an
annual Vocational Day. On this
day, prominent alumni who have
graduated into the mercantile and
professional world visit the Maine
college and attempt to advise the
students on their choice of a life
work by means of lectures and personal interviews.
A member of the insurance business, a teacher, a newspaper man, a
manufacturer, a banker, a clergyman and an advertising expert participated in the program this year.
*

*

*

Claiming that fraternities in
American colleges are antiquated
and useless, non-fraternity men at
Syracuse University have banded
together in an association to combat the Greeks. This union, backed
by the Syracuse administration and
having a membership of several
thousand may, in time, bring about
the abolition of fraternities at Syracuse.

Musical Club Receives
Wires From Radio Fans
Telegrams of congratulation received by Carl Lausch and the club
as a whole testified to the success
of the Musical Clubs' broadcasting
over Station WBAL last Friday
night. His rendition of Rachmaninoff's "Prelude in G Minor" was
especially enjoyed by the radio fans.
The program was similar to those
presented throughout the season in
the numerous concerts given by the
Musical Clubs this year. The Glee
Club, the Banjo Club, the now famous "Hawaiian Troupe", Lausch,
and J. Cookman Boyd, Jr. performed from 10 to 11 P. M.
The Glee Club is under the direction of Edgar T. Paul and the
Banjo Club is under the direction of
Conrad Gebelein.

ENGINEERS WILL
FROLIC SATURDAY
An informal dance will be
given in the C. E. Hall on Saturday, March 19, at nine
o'clock, by the Engineering
Societies. The student chapters of the American Institute
of Electrical Engineers, the
American Society of Mechanical Engineers, and the American Society of Civil Engineers
will sponsor the dance.
• The Blue Jay Orchestra will
furnish the music for the
dance. All Hopkins students
and their friends are invited.
Mr. and Mrs. Harold Lampe
and Mr. and Mrs. Comber will
be the chaperones.

HOMEWOOD. BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 15, 1927

WARFIELD TO LEAD
FRATERNITY BOARD
Ridgely Warfield was elected president of the Interfraternity Board for 1927-28 at
a meeting of the board held
at noon yesterday. He is a
member 'of .the Alpha Delta
Phi fraternity.
Philip Ness, a member of
Alpha Tau Omega, was chosen secretary-treasurer.
George Hebner, of Phi
Kappa Psi, was president during 1926-27, and Ross Macaulay, of Phi Gamma Delta,
was secretary-treasurer.

the offices of president and business

THE FUTURE OF ATHLETICS

Last season Hopkins put out a lacrosse team that won the national championship. The student body was, naturally, pleased
-and delighted; they are looking forward to another successful
year, for they like to watch their team win games. Saturday night
the Varsity Club, by dint of careful planning, Staged a highly successful smoker for some of the more prominent prep school men
in the state. Incidently- they managed to make the trophy room
look presentable for the first time in the memory of the oldest
living undergraduate. "Fine!" says the student body, "An excellent idea." For the past few seasons swimming has been the
only winter sport at the university. "What about basketball ?"
says the student body, and "We want a soccer team."
Thus it is plain that this mass of undergraduates, termed the
student body, has excellent intentions. In other words, it has
the right idea. It remains to be seen whether the men who make
it up have as much ability to act as they have to applaud or criticise. They may say that, taken as a whole, they are not athletes,
that there is nothing for them to do. But there is one thing that
they can do, a thing that must be done
The sports at Hopkins need money. A certain amount must
be gotten, in order that the existing teams be properly equipped.
With a greater sum new sports can be taken up.
A successful spring season ticket campaign means an advance
in Hopkins athletics; poor returns mean retrogression. The issue is put squarely into the hands of the student body, which has
always been quick enough to advise or encourage. Two or three
sales per man means success.

GONE ARE THE DAYS
During these spring days, when the activities, one after another are holding elections, and passing the leadership down to the
men of the junior class, we notice the almost complete absence
of a spirit which has too often been dominant on the campus.
No longer do such rumors as "So and so has twenty proxies,"
or "such and such fraternities • have combined" fly about the
campus. Politics on the campus seems very nearly a thing of
the past. The credit belongs to the senior class. Taken as a
group, the seniors are not as strong in numbers or in outstanding
men as some of the classes of former years; they have perhaps.
not made as many contributions to undergraduate life; but they
have accomplished a thing which before seemed practically impossible.
•
One wishing to be cynical might say that they lacked the
brains to play politics, but this is obviously an unfair statement.
The one thing Which marks the men who have directed the activities this year is a spirit of fair play and of mutual trust.
This all may sound like sentimental rot. Sentimental it may
be, but it is not rot by any means. The NEWS-LETUR has deplored conditions of former years too often to overlook the present change for the better. The situation has only one drawback;
future editors will be deprived of a fertile subject for burning
reform articles.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 15, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
In an effort to enlighten the college man regarding the opportunities in various businesses and professions, Bowdoin College has an
annual Vocational Day. On this
day, prominent alumni who have
graduated into the mercantile and
professional world visit the Maine
college and attempt to advise the
students on their choice of a life
work by means of lectures and personal interviews.
A member of the insurance business, a teacher, a newspaper man, a
manufacturer, a banker, a clergyman and an advertising expert participated in the program this year.
*

*

*

Claiming that fraternities in
American colleges are antiquated
and useless, non-fraternity men at
Syracuse University have banded
together in an association to combat the Greeks. This union, backed
by the Syracuse administration and
having a membership of several
thousand may, in time, bring about
the abolition of fraternities at Syracuse.

Musical Club Receives
Wires From Radio Fans
Telegrams of congratulation received by Carl Lausch and the club
as a whole testified to the success
of the Musical Clubs' broadcasting
over Station WBAL last Friday
night. His rendition of Rachmaninoff's "Prelude in G Minor" was
especially enjoyed by the radio fans.
The program was similar to those
presented throughout the season in
the numerous concerts given by the
Musical Clubs this year. The Glee
Club, the Banjo Club, the now famous "Hawaiian Troupe", Lausch,
and J. Cookman Boyd, Jr. performed from 10 to 11 P. M.
The Glee Club is under the direction of Edgar T. Paul and the
Banjo Club is under the direction of
Conrad Gebelein.

ENGINEERS WILL
FROLIC SATURDAY
An informal dance will be
given in the C. E. Hall on Saturday, March 19, at nine
o'clock, by the Engineering
Societies. The student chapters of the American Institute
of Electrical Engineers, the
American Society of Mechanical Engineers, and the American Society of Civil Engineers
will sponsor the dance.
• The Blue Jay Orchestra will
furnish the music for the
dance. All Hopkins students
and their friends are invited.
Mr. and Mrs. Harold Lampe
and Mr. and Mrs. Comber will
be the chaperones.
